• reset credentials used with mobile devices, including those used for remote access to their organisation’s systems
• monitor user accounts for any indicators of compromise, such as failed logon attempts.

Title from Copilot: Prefer PP-evaluated products when procuring evaluated products
Description from ISM: If procuring an evaluated product, a product that has completed a PP-based evaluation, including against all applicable PP modules (as well as a software bill of materials assessment if applicable), is selected in preference to one that has completed an EAL-based evaluation.

Title from Copilot: Deliver evaluated products per evaluation docs
Description from ISM: Evaluated products are delivered in a manner consistent with any delivery procedures defined in associated evaluation documentation.

Title from Copilot: Contact ASD for high-assurance IT delivery procedures
Description from ISM: When procuring high assurance information technology (IT) equipment, ASD is contacted for any equipment-specific delivery procedures.

Title from Copilot: Install evaluated products in evaluated configuration per vendor guidance
Description from ISM: Evaluated products are installed, configured, administered and operated in an evaluated configuration and in accordance with vendor guidance.

Title from Copilot: High-assurance IT operated per ASD guidance and evaluated config
Description from ISM: High assurance IT equipment is installed, configured, administered and operated in an evaluated configuration and in accordance with ASD guidance.

Title from Copilot: IT equipment management policy maintained
Description from ISM: An IT equipment management policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Approved configurations for IT equipment maintained
Description from ISM: Approved configurations for IT equipment are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Harden IT equipment using ASD/vendor guidance (most restrictive)
Description from ISM: IT equipment is hardened using ASD and vendor hardening guidance, with the most restrictive guidance taking precedence when conflicts occur.

Title from Copilot: Networked IT equipment register maintained
Description from ISM: A networked IT equipment register is developed, implemented, maintained and verified on a regular basis.

Title from Copilot: Non-networked IT equipment register maintained
Description from ISM: A non-networked IT equipment register is developed, implemented, maintained and verified on a regular basis.

Title from Copilot: Label IT equipment (except high-assurance) with protective markings
Description from ISM: IT equipment, with the exception of high assurance IT equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

Title from Copilot: Seek ASD approval before labeling high-assurance external surfaces
Description from ISM: ASD’s approval is sought before applying labels to external surfaces of high assurance IT equipment.

Title from Copilot: Classify IT equipment by highest data sensitivity it can handle
Description from ISM: IT equipment is classified based on the highest sensitivity or classification of data that it is approved for processing, storing or communicating.

Title from Copilot: Handle IT equipment suitably for its sensitivity
Description from ISM: IT equipment is handled in a manner suitable for its sensitivity or classification.

Title from Copilot: Seek ASD approval before maintenance on high-assurance equipment
Description from ISM: ASD’s approval is sought before undertaking any maintenance or repairs to high assurance IT equipment.

Title from Copilot: On-site maintenance by appropriately cleared technician
Description from ISM: Maintenance and repairs of IT equipment is carried out on site by an appropriately cleared technician.

Title from Copilot: If not cleared, sanitise equipment or escort technician
Description from ISM: If an appropriately cleared technician is not used to undertake maintenance or repairs of IT equipment, the IT equipment and associated media is sanitised before maintenance or repair work is undertaken.

Title from Copilot: Escort non-cleared technician with cleared, briefed escort
Description from ISM:
If an appropriately cleared technician is not used to undertake maintenance or repairs of IT equipment, the technician is escorted by someone who:
• is appropriately cleared and briefed
• takes due care to ensure that data is not disclosed
• takes all responsible measures to ensure the integrity of the IT equipment
• has the authority to direct the technician
• is sufficiently familiar with the IT equipment to understand the work being performed.

Title from Copilot: Off-site maintenance at approved facilities
Description from ISM: IT equipment maintained or repaired off site is done so at facilities approved for handling the sensitivity or classification of the IT equipment.

Title from Copilot: Post-maintenance inspection confirms configuration and integrity
Description from ISM: Following maintenance or repair activities for IT equipment, the IT equipment is inspected to confirm it retains its approved configuration and that no unauthorised modifications have taken place.

Title from Copilot: IT equipment sanitisation processes maintained
Description from ISM: IT equipment sanitisation processes, and supporting IT equipment sanitisation procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: IT equipment destruction processes maintained
Description from ISM: IT equipment destruction processes, and supporting IT equipment destruction procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Sanitise IT equipment by removing or sanitising media
Description from ISM: IT equipment containing media is sanitised by removing the media from the IT equipment or by sanitising the media in situ.

Title from Copilot: Destroy IT equipment that cannot be sanitised
Description from ISM: IT equipment that cannot be sanitised is destroyed.

Title from Copilot: Sanitise overseas equipment in situ processing AUSTEO/AGAO
Description from ISM: IT equipment, including associated media, that is located overseas and has processed, stored or communicated AUSTEO or AGAO data, is sanitised in situ.

Title from Copilot: Return overseas equipment for destruction if cannot sanitise in situ
Description from ISM: IT equipment, including associated media, that is located overseas and has processed, stored or communicated AUSTEO or AGAO data that cannot be sanitised in situ, is returned to Australia for destruction.

Title from Copilot: Destroy high-assurance IT equipment before disposal
Description from ISM: High assurance IT equipment is destroyed prior to its disposal.

Title from Copilot: Print random text on each colour printer cartridge/drum
Description from ISM: At least three pages of random text with no blank areas are printed on each colour printer cartridge or MFD print drum.

Title from Copilot: Inspect/destroy MFD print drums if remnant toner visible
Description from ISM: MFD print drums and image transfer rollers are inspected and destroyed if there is remnant toner which cannot be removed or a print is visible on the image transfer roller.

Title from Copilot: Inspect/destroy printer platens if images/text retained
Description from ISM: Printer and MFD platens are inspected and destroyed if any text or images are retained on the platen.

Title from Copilot: Check printers/MFDs for trapped pages after jams
Description from ISM: Printers and MFDs are checked to ensure no pages are trapped in the paper path due to a paper jam.

Title from Copilot: Destroy cartridges/drums as electrostatic memory devices when unsanitizable
Description from ISM: When unable to sanitise printer cartridges or MFD print drums, they are destroyed as per electrostatic memory devices.

Title from Copilot: Remove and destroy printer ribbons
Description from ISM: Printer ribbons in printers and MFDs are removed and destroyed.

Title from Copilot: Sanitise monitors by displaying solid white image for burn-in
Description from ISM: Televisions and computer monitors with minor burn-in or image persistence are sanitised by displaying a solid white image on the screen for an extended period of time.

Title from Copilot: Destroy monitors that cannot be sanitised
Description from ISM: Televisions and computer monitors that cannot be sanitised are destroyed.

Title from Copilot: Sanitise network device memory per preference order
Description from ISM:
Memory in network devices is sanitised using the following processes, in order of preference:
• following device-specific guidance provided in evaluation documentation
• following vendor sanitisation guidance
• loading a dummy configuration file, performing a factory reset and then reinstalling firmware.

Title from Copilot: IT equipment disposal processes maintained
Description from ISM: IT equipment disposal processes, and supporting IT equipment disposal procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Remove owner/sensitivity markings before disposal
Description from ISM: Labels and markings indicating the owner, sensitivity, classification or any other marking that can associate IT equipment with its prior use are removed prior to its disposal.

Title from Copilot: Contact ASD for disposal of emanation-secured equipment
Description from ISM: When disposing of IT equipment that has been designed or modified to meet emanation security standards, ASD is contacted for requirements relating to its disposal.

Title from Copilot: Formal administrative decision to release sanitised/destroyed equipment
Description from ISM: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to release IT equipment, or its waste, into the public domain.

Title from Copilot: Media management policy maintained
Description from ISM: A media management policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Removable media usage policy maintained
Description from ISM: A removable media usage policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Removable media register maintained
Description from ISM: A removable media register is developed, implemented, maintained and verified on a regular basis.

Title from Copilot: Label media with protective markings
Description from ISM: Media, with the exception of internally mounted fixed media within information technology equipment, is labelled with protective markings reflecting its sensitivity or classification.

Title from Copilot: Classify media by highest sensitivity of its contents
Description from ISM: Media is classified to the highest sensitivity or classification of data it stores, unless the media has been classified to a higher sensitivity or classification.

Title from Copilot: Use media only with authorised systems
Description from ISM: Media is only used with systems that are authorised to process, store or communicate its sensitivity or classification.

Title from Copilot: Reclassify media when connected to higher sensitivity systems
Description from ISM: Any media connected to a system with a higher sensitivity or classification than the media is reclassified to the higher sensitivity or classification, unless the media is read-only or the system has a mechanism through which read-only access can be ensured.

Title from Copilot: Sanitise/destroy before lowering media classification
Description from ISM: Before reclassifying media to a lower sensitivity or classification, the media is sanitised or destroyed, and a formal administrative decision is made to reclassify it.

Title from Copilot: Handle media per sensitivity/classification
Description from ISM: Media is handled in a manner suitable for its sensitivity or classification.

Title from Copilot: Encrypt all data on media
Description from ISM: All data stored on media is encrypted.

Title from Copilot: Sanitise media before first use
Description from ISM: Media is sanitised before it is used for the first time.

Title from Copilot: Sanitise media before reuse in different domain
Description from ISM: Media is sanitised before it is reused in a different security domain.

Title from Copilot: Use write-once media for manual transfers between domains
Description from ISM: When transferring data manually between two systems belonging to different security domains, write-once media is used unless the destination system has a mechanism through which read-only access can be ensured.

Title from Copilot: Sanitise rewritable media after manual transfer
Description from ISM: When transferring data manually between two systems belonging to different security domains, rewritable media is sanitised after each data transfer.

Title from Copilot: Media sanitisation processes maintained
Description from ISM: Media sanitisation processes, and supporting media sanitisation procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Volatile media sanitised by removing power >=10 minutes
Description from ISM: Volatile media is sanitised by removing its power for at least 10 minutes.

Title from Copilot: SECRET/TOP SECRET volatile media overwritten & verified
Description from ISM: SECRET and TOP SECRET volatile media is sanitised by overwriting it at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

Title from Copilot: TOP SECRET volatile media retains classification after extended use
Description from ISM: Following sanitisation, TOP SECRET volatile media retains its classification if it stored static data for an extended period of time, or had data repeatedly stored on or written to the same memory location for an extended period of time.

Title from Copilot: Non-volatile magnetic media sanitised by overwriting (& verify)
Description from ISM: Non-volatile magnetic media is sanitised by overwriting it at least once (or three times if pre-2001 or under 15 GB) in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

Title from Copilot: Reset HPA/Device config before hard drive sanitisation
Description from ISM: The host-protected area and device configuration overlay table are reset prior to the sanitisation of non-volatile magnetic hard drives.

Title from Copilot: Use ATA secure erase in addition to overwriting
Description from ISM: The ATA secure erase command is used, in addition to block overwriting software, to ensure the growth defects table of non-volatile magnetic hard drives is overwritten.

Title from Copilot: SECRET/TOP SECRET non-volatile magnetic media retains classification
Description from ISM: Following sanitisation, SECRET and TOP SECRET non-volatile magnetic media retains its classification.

Title from Copilot: Non-volatile EPROM sanitised by extended UV + overwrite & verify
Description from ISM: Non-volatile EPROM media is sanitised by applying three times the manufacturer’s specified ultraviolet erasure time and then overwriting it at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

Title from Copilot: EEPROM sanitised by overwrite & verify
Description from ISM: Non-volatile EEPROM media is sanitised by overwriting it at least once in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

Title from Copilot: SECRET/TOP SECRET EPROM/EEPROM retains classification
Description from ISM: Following sanitisation, SECRET and TOP SECRET non-volatile EPROM and EEPROM media retains its classification.

Title from Copilot: Flash memory sanitised by overwriting twice & verify
Description from ISM: Non-volatile flash memory media is sanitised by overwriting it at least twice in its entirety with a random pattern followed by a read back for verification.

Title from Copilot: SECRET/TOP SECRET flash retains classification after sanitisation
Description from ISM: Following sanitisation, SECRET and TOP SECRET non-volatile flash memory media retains its classification.

Title from Copilot: Destroy media that cannot be sanitised
Description from ISM: Media that cannot be successfully sanitised is destroyed prior to its disposal.

Title from Copilot: Media destruction processes maintained
Description from ISM: Media destruction processes, and supporting media destruction procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Certain media types destroyed prior to disposal
Description from ISM:
The following media types are destroyed prior to their disposal:
• microfiche and microfilm
• optical discs
• programmable read-only memory
• read-only memory
• other types of media that cannot be sanitised.

Title from Copilot: Use SCEC/ASIO-approved equipment for media destruction
Description from ISM: Security Construction and Equipment Committee-approved equipment or ASIO-approved equipment is used when destroying media.

Title from Copilot: Use NSA-evaluated degaussers if degaussing
Description from ISM: If using degaussers to destroy media, degaussers evaluated by the United States’ National Security Agency are used.

Title from Copilot: Use fine-powder-capable equipment for microform destruction
Description from ISM: Equipment that is capable of reducing microform to a fine powder, with resultant particles not showing more than five consecutive characters per particle upon microscopic inspection, is used to destroy microfiche and microfilm.

Title from Copilot: Destroy electrostatic memory devices using approved equipment
Description from ISM: Electrostatic memory devices are destroyed using a furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator or grinder/sander.

Title from Copilot: Destroy magnetic floppy disks by approved methods
Description from ISM: Magnetic floppy disks are destroyed using a furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator, degausser or by cutting.

Title from Copilot: Destroy magnetic hard disks by approved methods
Description from ISM: Magnetic hard disks are destroyed using a furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator, grinder/sander or degausser.

Title from Copilot: Destroy magnetic tapes by approved methods
Description from ISM: Magnetic tapes are destroyed using a furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator, degausser or by cutting.

Title from Copilot: Destroy optical disks by approved methods
Description from ISM: Optical disks are destroyed using a furnace/incinerator, hammer mill, disintegrator, grinder/sander or by cutting.

Title from Copilot: Destroy semiconductor memory by approved methods
Description from ISM: Semiconductor memory is destroyed using a furnace/incinerator, hammer mill or disintegrator.

Title from Copilot: Media waste particles <=9mm after mechanical destruction
Description from ISM: Media destroyed using a hammer mill, disintegrator, grinder/sander or by cutting results in media waste particles no larger than 9 mm.

Title from Copilot: SECRET media waste handling by particle size
Description from ISM: The resulting media waste particles from the destruction of SECRET media is stored and handled as OFFICIAL if less than or equal to 3 mm, PROTECTED if greater than 3 mm and less than or equal to 6 mm, or SECRET if greater than 6 mm and less than or equal to 9 mm.

Title from Copilot: TOP SECRET media waste handling by particle size
Description from ISM: The resulting media waste particles from the destruction of TOP SECRET media is stored and handled as OFFICIAL if less than or equal to 3 mm, or SECRET if greater than 3 mm and less than or equal to 9 mm.

Title from Copilot: Use degausser with suitable field/orientation for magnetic media
Description from ISM: Magnetic media is destroyed using a degausser with a suitable magnetic field strength and magnetic orientation.

Title from Copilot: Follow manufacturer directions for degaussers
Description from ISM: Product-specific directions provided by degausser manufacturers are followed.

Title from Copilot: Physically damage platters after degaussing
Description from ISM: Following the use of a degausser, magnetic media is physically damaged by deforming any internal platters.

Title from Copilot: Destruction supervised by at least one cleared person
Description from ISM: The destruction of media is performed under the supervision of at least one cleared person.

Title from Copilot: Supervisors ensure destruction completion
Description from ISM: Personnel supervising the destruction of media supervise its handling to the point of destruction and ensure that the destruction is completed successfully.

Title from Copilot: Destruction of accountable material supervised by two cleared personnel
Description from ISM: The destruction of media storing accountable material is performed under the supervision of at least two cleared personnel.

Title from Copilot: Supervise accountable material destruction and sign certificate
Description from ISM: Personnel supervising the destruction of media storing accountable material supervise its handling to the point of destruction, ensure that the destruction is completed successfully and sign a destruction certificate afterwards.

Title from Copilot: Do not outsource destruction of accountable material
Description from ISM: The destruction of media storing accountable material is not outsourced.

Title from Copilot: Use certified services for non-accountable material destruction when outsourced
Description from ISM: When outsourcing the destruction of media storing non-accountable material, a National Association for Information Destruction AAA certified destruction service with endorsements, as specified in ASIO’s Protective Security Circular-167, is used.

Title from Copilot: Media disposal processes maintained
Description from ISM: Media disposal processes, and supporting media disposal procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Remove labels/markings before disposal
Description from ISM: Labels and markings indicating the owner, sensitivity, classification or any other marking that can associate media with its prior use are removed prior to its disposal.

Title from Copilot: Formal decision to release media after sanitisation/destruction
Description from ISM: Following sanitisation, destruction or declassification, a formal administrative decision is made to release media, or its waste, into the public domain.

Title from Copilot: Use vendors committed to Secure by Design for OS vendors
Description from ISM: Vendors that have demonstrated a commitment to Secure by Design and Secure by Default principles and practices, including secure programming practices and either memory-safe programming languages or less preferably memory-safe programming practices, are used for operating systems.

Title from Copilot: Use latest or previous OS release
Description from ISM: The latest release, or the previous release, of operating systems are used.

Title from Copilot: Use 64-bit OS versions where supported
Description from ISM: Where supported, 64-bit versions of operating systems are used.

Title from Copilot: Use Standard Operating Environments (SOEs)
Description from ISM: SOEs are used for workstations and servers.

Title from Copilot: Scan third-party SOEs for malicious code/configs
Description from ISM: SOEs provided by third parties are scanned for malicious code and configurations.

Title from Copilot: Review and update SOEs at least annually
Description from ISM: SOEs are reviewed and updated at least annually.

Title from Copilot: Approved OS configurations maintained
Description from ISM: Approved configurations for operating systems are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Harden OS using ASD/vendor guidance (most restrictive)
Description from ISM: Operating systems are hardened using ASD and vendor hardening guidance, with the most restrictive guidance taking precedence when conflicts occur.

Title from Copilot: Change/disable/remove default OS accounts/credentials
Description from ISM: Default user accounts or credentials for operating systems, including for any pre-configured user accounts, are changed, disabled or removed during initial setup.

Title from Copilot: Disable/remove unneeded OS accounts/services
Description from ISM: Unneeded user accounts, components, services and functionality of operating systems are disabled or removed.

Title from Copilot: Disable autorun for removable media
Description from ISM: Automatic execution features for removable media are disabled.

Title from Copilot: Disable/remove Internet Explorer 11
Description from ISM: Internet Explorer 11 is disabled or removed.

Title from Copilot: Disable/remove .NET Framework 3.5
Description from ISM: .NET Framework 3.5 (includes .NET 2.0 and 3.0) is disabled or removed.

Title from Copilot: Enable OS exploit protection features
Description from ISM: Operating system exploit protection functionality is enabled.

Title from Copilot: Enable Early Launch Antimalware, Secure Boot, Trusted Boot, Measured Boot
Description from ISM: Early Launch Antimalware, Secure Boot, Trusted Boot and Measured Boot functionality is enabled.

Title from Copilot: Prevent unprivileged bypass/disable of OS security
Description from ISM: Unprivileged users are prevented from bypassing, disabling or modifying security functionality of operating systems.

Title from Copilot: Prevent unprivileged users running script engines
Description from ISM:
Unprivileged users are prevented from running script execution engines, including:
• Windows Script Host (cscript.exe and wscript.exe)
• PowerShell (powershell.exe, powershell_ise.exe and pwsh.exe)
• Command Prompt (cmd.exe)
• Windows Management Instrumentation (wmic.exe)
• Microsoft Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) Application Host (mshta.exe).

Title from Copilot: Prevent unprivileged users installing unapproved apps
Description from ISM: Unprivileged users do not have the ability to install unapproved applications.

Title from Copilot: Prevent unprivileged users uninstalling approved apps
Description from ISM: Unprivileged users do not have the ability to uninstall or disable approved applications.

Title from Copilot: Implement application control on workstations
Description from ISM: Application control is implemented on workstations.

Title from Copilot: Implement application control on internet-facing servers
Description from ISM: Application control is implemented on internet-facing servers.

Title from Copilot: Implement application control on non-internet-facing servers
Description from ISM: Application control is implemented on non-internet-facing servers.

Title from Copilot: Apply app control to profiles & temp folders for OS/browsers/email
Description from ISM: Application control is applied to user profiles and temporary folders used by operating systems, web browsers and email clients.

Title from Copilot: Apply app control to all locations except user profiles/temp folders
Description from ISM: Application control is applied to all locations other than user profiles and temporary folders used by operating systems, web browsers and email clients.

Title from Copilot: App control restricts execs/libraries/scripts to approved set
Description from ISM: Application control restricts the execution of executables, libraries, scripts, installers, compiled HTML, HTML applications and control panel applets to an organisation-approved set.

Title from Copilot: App control restricts drivers to approved set
Description from ISM: Application control restricts the execution of drivers to an organisation-approved set.

Title from Copilot: Implement app control using hash/publisher/path rules
Description from ISM: Application control is implemented using cryptographic hash rules, publisher certificate rules or path rules.

Title from Copilot: Use publisher/product names when using publisher certificate rules
Description from ISM: When implementing application control using publisher certificate rules, publisher names and product names are used.

Title from Copilot: Restrict path-rule modifications to approved users
Description from ISM: When implementing application control using path rules, only approved users can modify approved files and write to approved folders.

Title from Copilot: Require approved users to change file permissions when using path rules
Description from ISM: When implementing application control using path rules, only approved users can change file system permissions for approved files and folders.

Title from Copilot: Implement Microsoft's recommended application blocklist
Description from ISM: Microsoft’s recommended application blocklist is implemented.

Title from Copilot: Implement Microsoft's vulnerable driver blocklist
Description from ISM: Microsoft’s vulnerable driver blocklist is implemented.

Title from Copilot: Validate app control rulesets annually or more often
Description from ISM: Application control rulesets are validated on an annual or more frequent basis.

Title from Copilot: Users (except local admin/break glass) cannot disable app control
Description from ISM: All users (with the exception of local administrator accounts and break glass accounts) cannot disable, bypass or be exempted from application control.

Title from Copilot: Log allowed/blocked app control events centrally
Description from ISM: Allowed and blocked application control events are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Log command-line process creation centrally
Description from ISM: Command line process creation events are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Disable or remove PowerShell 2.0
Description from ISM: Windows PowerShell 2.0 is disabled or removed.

Title from Copilot: Configure PowerShell Constrained Language Mode
Description from ISM: PowerShell is configured to use Constrained Language Mode.

Title from Copilot: Log PowerShell module/script/transcription events centrally
Description from ISM: PowerShell module logging, script block logging and transcription events are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Protect script block logs with Protected Event Logging
Description from ISM: PowerShell script block logs are protected by Protected Event Logging functionality.

Title from Copilot: Implement HIPS/EDR on workstations
Description from ISM: A HIPS or EDR solution is implemented on workstations.

Title from Copilot: Implement HIPS/EDR on critical & high-value servers
Description from ISM: A HIPS or EDR solution is implemented on critical servers and high-value servers.

Title from Copilot: Implement software firewall on workstations/servers
Description from ISM: A software firewall is implemented on workstations and servers to restrict inbound and outbound network connections to an organisation-approved set of applications and services.

Title from Copilot: Implement antivirus with comprehensive protections & daily updates
Description from ISM:
An antivirus application is implemented on workstations and servers with:
• signature-based detection functionality enabled and set to a high level
• heuristic-based detection functionality enabled and set to a high level
• reputation rating functionality enabled
• ransomware protection functionality enabled
• detection signatures configured to update on at least a daily basis
• regular scanning configured for all fixed disks and removable media.

Title from Copilot: Disable read-from removable media if not required
Description from ISM: If there is no business requirement for reading from removable media and devices, such functionality is disabled via the use of a device access control application or by disabling external communication interfaces.

Title from Copilot: Disable write-to removable media if not required
Description from ISM: If there is no business requirement for writing to removable media and devices, such functionality is disabled via the use of a device access control application or by disabling external communication interfaces.

Title from Copilot: Disable DMA-capable external interfaces
Description from ISM: External communication interfaces that allow DMA are disabled.

Title from Copilot: Log macOS security events centrally
Description from ISM: Security-relevant events for Apple macOS operating systems are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Log Linux security events centrally
Description from ISM: Security-relevant events for Linux operating systems are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Log Windows security events centrally
Description from ISM: Security-relevant events for Microsoft Windows operating systems are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Use Secure by Design vendors for user applications
Description from ISM: Vendors that have demonstrated a commitment to Secure by Design and Secure by Default principles and practices, including secure programming practices and either memory-safe programming languages or less preferably memory-safe programming practices, are used for user applications.

Title from Copilot: Use latest releases of office/browser/email/PDF/security products
Description from ISM: The latest release of office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, and security products are used.

Title from Copilot: Approved configurations for user applications maintained
Description from ISM: Approved configurations for user applications are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Change/disable/remove default user app accounts/credentials
Description from ISM: Default user accounts or credentials for user applications, including for any pre-configured user accounts, are changed, disabled or removed during initial setup.

Title from Copilot: Disable/remove unneeded components in user apps
Description from ISM: Unneeded components, services and functionality of office productivity suites, web browsers, email clients, PDF applications and security products are disabled or removed.

Title from Copilot: Restrict add-ons/extensions to approved set
Description from ISM: Add-ons, extensions and plug-ins for office productivity suites, web browsers, email clients, PDF applications and security products are restricted to an organisation-approved set.

Title from Copilot: Block Microsoft Office from creating child processes
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office is blocked from creating child processes.

Title from Copilot: Block Office from creating executable content
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office is blocked from creating executable content.

Title from Copilot: Block Office from injecting code into other processes
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office is blocked from injecting code into other processes.

Title from Copilot: Prevent activation of OLE packages in Office
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office is configured to prevent activation of Object Linking and Embedding packages.

Title from Copilot: Harden office suites using ASD/vendor guidance
Description from ISM: Office productivity suites are hardened using ASD and vendor hardening guidance, with the most restrictive guidance taking precedence when conflicts occur.

Title from Copilot: Prevent users changing office security settings
Description from ISM: Office productivity suite security settings cannot be changed by users.

Title from Copilot: Block Java in web browsers from the internet
Description from ISM: Web browsers do not process Java from the internet.

Title from Copilot: Block web ads in browsers
Description from ISM: Web browsers do not process web advertisements from the internet.

Title from Copilot: Harden web browsers using ASD/vendor guidance
Description from ISM: Web browsers are hardened using ASD and vendor hardening guidance, with the most restrictive guidance taking precedence when conflicts occur.

Title from Copilot: Prevent users changing browser security settings
Description from ISM: Web browser security settings cannot be changed by users.

Title from Copilot: Block PDF apps from creating child processes
Description from ISM: PDF applications are blocked from creating child processes.

Title from Copilot: Harden PDF apps using ASD/vendor guidance
Description from ISM: PDF applications are hardened using ASD and vendor hardening guidance, with the most restrictive guidance taking precedence when conflicts occur.

Title from Copilot: Prevent users changing PDF app security settings
Description from ISM: PDF application security settings cannot be changed by users.

Title from Copilot: Implement Microsoft attack surface reduction rules
Description from ISM: Microsoft’s attack surface reduction rules are implemented.

Title from Copilot: Prevent users changing email client security settings
Description from ISM: Email client security settings cannot be changed by users.

Title from Copilot: Prevent users changing security product settings
Description from ISM: Security product security settings cannot be changed by users.

Title from Copilot: Disable Office macros for users without business need
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office macros are disabled for users that do not have a demonstrated business requirement.

Title from Copilot: Block macros from internet-origin files
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office macros in files originating from the internet are blocked.

Title from Copilot: Enable macro antivirus scanning
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office macro antivirus scanning is enabled.

Title from Copilot: Block macros from making Win32 API calls
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office macros are blocked from making Win32 API calls.

Title from Copilot: Allow only sandboxed/trusted/signed macros
Description from ISM: Only Microsoft Office macros running from within a sandboxed environment, a Trusted Location or that are digitally signed by a trusted publisher are allowed to execute.

Title from Copilot: Check macros for malicious code before signing/trusted placement
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office macros are checked to ensure they are free of malicious code before being digitally signed or placed within Trusted Locations.

Title from Copilot: Only privileged users can modify Trusted Locations
Description from ISM: Only privileged users responsible for checking that Microsoft Office macros are free of malicious code can write to and modify content within Trusted Locations.

Title from Copilot: Untrusted-publisher signed macros cannot be enabled via UI
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office macros digitally signed by an untrusted publisher cannot be enabled via the Message Bar or Backstage View.

Title from Copilot: Non-V3 signatures cannot enable macros via UI
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office macros digitally signed by signatures other than V3 signatures cannot be enabled via the Message Bar or Backstage View.

Title from Copilot: Validate trusted publishers list annually or more
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office’s list of trusted publishers is validated on an annual or more frequent basis.

Title from Copilot: Prevent users changing macro security settings
Description from ISM: Microsoft Office macro security settings cannot be changed by users.

Title from Copilot: Use secure-by-design vendors for server applications
Description from ISM: Vendors that have demonstrated a commitment to Secure by Design and Secure by Default principles and practices, including secure programming practices and either memory-safe programming languages or less preferably memory-safe programming practices, are used for server applications.

Title from Copilot: Use latest release of internet-facing server apps
Description from ISM: The latest release of internet-facing server applications are used.

Title from Copilot: Approved configurations for server apps maintained
Description from ISM: Approved configurations for server applications are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Harden server apps using ASD/vendor guidance
Description from ISM: Server applications are hardened using ASD and vendor hardening guidance, with the most restrictive guidance taking precedence when conflicts occur.

Title from Copilot: Change/disable/remove default server app accounts/credentials
Description from ISM: Default user accounts or credentials for server applications, including for any pre-configured user accounts, are changed, disabled or removed during initial setup.

Title from Copilot: Disable/remove unneeded server app components/services
Description from ISM: Unneeded user accounts, components, services and functionality of server applications are disabled or removed.

Title from Copilot: Remove install files/logs after server app installation
Description from ISM: All temporary installation files and logs created during server application installation processes are removed after server applications have been installed.

Title from Copilot: Run server apps as separate low-privilege user
Description from ISM: Server applications are configured to run as a separate user account with the minimum privileges needed to perform their functions.

Title from Copilot: Limit app user accounts' file system access
Description from ISM: The user accounts under which server applications run have limited access to their underlying server’s file system.

Title from Copilot: Use domain controllers only for designed role
Description from ISM: Microsoft AD DS domain controllers, Microsoft AD CS CA servers, Microsoft AD FS servers and Microsoft Entra Connect servers are only used for their designed role and no other applications or services are installed, unless they are security related.

Title from Copilot: Limit access to AD critical servers to required privileged users
Description from ISM: Access to Microsoft AD DS domain controllers, Microsoft AD CS CA servers, Microsoft AD FS servers and Microsoft Entra Connect servers is limited to privileged users that require access.

Title from Copilot: Encrypt and secure backups for AD/CA/FS/Entra Connect servers
Description from ISM: Backups of Microsoft AD DS domain controllers, Microsoft AD CS CA servers, Microsoft AD FS servers and Microsoft Entra Connect servers are encrypted, stored securely and only accessible to backup administrator accounts.

Title from Copilot: Log security events for AD critical servers centrally
Description from ISM: Security-relevant events for Microsoft AD DS domain controllers, Microsoft AD CS CA servers, Microsoft AD FS servers and Microsoft Entra Connect servers are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Admin AD using dedicated domain admin accounts
Description from ISM: Microsoft AD DS domain controllers are administered using dedicated domain administrator user accounts that are not used to administer other systems.

Title from Copilot: Enable LDAP signing on AD domain controllers
Description from ISM: Lightweight Directory Access Protocol signing is enabled on Microsoft AD DS domain controllers.

Title from Copilot: Disable Print Spooler on AD domain controllers
Description from ISM: The Print Spooler service is disabled on Microsoft AD DS domain controllers.

Title from Copilot: Do not store passwords in GPP
Description from ISM: Passwords are not stored in Group Policy Preferences.

Title from Copilot: Prevent storing passwords in GPP
Description from ISM: Passwords are prevented from being stored in Group Policy Preferences.

Title from Copilot: Enable SID Filtering for trusts
Description from ISM: SID Filtering is enabled for domain and forest trusts.

Title from Copilot: Only service/computer accounts have SPNs
Description from ISM: Only service accounts and computer accounts are configured with Service Principal Names (SPNs).

Title from Copilot: Minimise service accounts with SPNs
Description from ISM: The number of service accounts configured with an SPN is minimised.

Title from Copilot: Service accounts with SPNs lack DCSync
Description from ISM: Service accounts configured with an SPN do not have DCSync permissions.

Title from Copilot: Service accounts with SPNs use AES encryption
Description from ISM: Service accounts configured with an SPN use the Advanced Encryption Standard for encryption.

Title from Copilot: Prevent duplicate SPNs
Description from ISM: Duplicate SPNs do not exist within the domain.

Title from Copilot: Provision user accounts with least privilege
Description from ISM: User accounts are provisioned with the minimum privileges required.

Title from Copilot: Review DCSync permissions annually
Description from ISM: User accounts with DCSync permissions are reviewed at least annually, and those without an ongoing requirement for the permissions have them removed.

Title from Copilot: Configure privileged accounts as sensitive/non-delegable
Description from ISM: Privileged user accounts are configured as sensitive and cannot be delegated.

Title from Copilot: Prevent unconstrained delegation for computer accounts
Description from ISM: Computer accounts are not configured for unconstrained delegation.

Title from Copilot: Require Kerberos pre-authentication
Description from ISM: User accounts require Kerberos pre-authentication.

Title from Copilot: Do not set password never expires or not required
Description from ISM: User accounts are not configured with password never expires or password not required.

Title from Copilot: Do not use UserPassword attribute
Description from ISM: The UserPassword attribute for user accounts is not used.

Title from Copilot: Do not use sIDHistory
Description from ISM: The sIDHistory attribute for user accounts is not used.

Title from Copilot: Check sIDHistory weekly
Description from ISM: User accounts are checked at least weekly for the presence of the sIDHistory attribute.

Title from Copilot: Do not store passwords in accessible account properties
Description from ISM: Account properties accessible by unprivileged users are not used to store passwords.

Title from Copilot: Do not use reversible encryption for passwords
Description from ISM: User account passwords do not use reversible encryption.

Title from Copilot: Unprivileged users cannot add machines to domain
Description from ISM: Unprivileged user accounts cannot add machines to the domain.

Title from Copilot: Use dedicated privileged service accounts to add machines
Description from ISM: Dedicated privileged service accounts are used to add machines to the domain.

Title from Copilot: Review unconstrained delegation annually
Description from ISM: User accounts with unconstrained delegation are reviewed at least annually, and those without an SPN or demonstrated business requirement are removed.

Title from Copilot: Non-DC computer accounts not trusted for delegation
Description from ISM: Computer accounts that are not Microsoft AD DS domain controllers are not trusted for delegation to services.

Title from Copilot: Domain Computers group has no write/modify AD permissions
Description from ISM: The Domain Computers security group does not have write or modify permissions to any Microsoft Active Directory objects.

Title from Copilot: Privileged users are in Protected Users group
Description from ISM: Privileged user accounts are members of the Protected Users security group.

Title from Copilot: Minimise members of highly-privileged groups
Description from ISM: The number of user accounts that are members of the Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins or other highly-privileged security groups is minimised.

Title from Copilot: Service accounts not in privileged groups
Description from ISM: Service accounts are not members of the Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins or other highly-privileged security groups.

Title from Copilot: Computer accounts not in privileged groups
Description from ISM: Computer accounts are not members of the Domain Admins, Enterprise Admins or other highly-privileged security groups.

Title from Copilot: Domain Computers group not member of privileged groups
Description from ISM: The Domain Computers security group is not a member of any privileged or highly-privileged security groups.

Title from Copilot: Remove disabled accounts from groups
Description from ISM: When a user account is disabled, it is removed from all security group memberships.

Title from Copilot: Pre-Windows 2000 group contains no user accounts
Description from ISM: The Pre-Windows 2000 Compatible Access security group does not contain user accounts.

Title from Copilot: Enforce strong certificate-user mapping
Description from ISM: Strong mapping between certificates and users is enforced.

Title from Copilot: Remove EDITF_ATTRIBUTESUBJECTALTNAME2 flag from CA
Description from ISM: The EDITF_ATTRIBUTESUBJECTALTNAME2 flag is removed from Microsoft AD CS CA configurations.

Title from Copilot: Remove CT_FLAG_ENROLLEE_SUPPLIES_SUBJECT from templates
Description from ISM: The CT_FLAG_ENROLLEE_SUPPLIES_SUBJECT flag is removed from certificate templates.

Title from Copilot: Prevent unprivileged write access to certificate templates
Description from ISM: Unprivileged user accounts do not have write access to certificate templates.

Title from Copilot: Remove user-authentication EKUs
Description from ISM: Extended Key Usages that enable user authentication are removed.

Title from Copilot: Require CA approval for templates allowing SAN supply
Description from ISM: CA Certificate Manager approval is required for certificate templates that allow a Subject Alternative Name to be supplied.

Title from Copilot: Administer AD FS with dedicated service account
Description from ISM: Microsoft AD FS servers are administered using a dedicated service account that is not used to administer other systems.

Title from Copilot: Disable soft matching after initial sync
Description from ISM: Soft matching between Microsoft AD DS and Microsoft Entra ID is disabled following initial synchronisation activities.

Title from Copilot: Disable hard match takeover for Entra Connect
Description from ISM: Hard match takeover is disabled for Microsoft Entra Connect servers.

Title from Copilot: Do not sync privileged accounts between AD and Entra
Description from ISM: Privileged user accounts are not synchronised between Microsoft AD DS and Microsoft Entra ID.

Title from Copilot: Log security events for internet-facing server apps centrally
Description from ISM: Security-relevant events for server applications on internet-facing servers are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Log security events for non-internet-facing server apps centrally
Description from ISM: Security-relevant events for server applications on non-internet-facing servers are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Authenticate users before granting system access
Description from ISM: Users are authenticated before they are granted access to a system and its resources.

Title from Copilot: Disable replay-susceptible authentication methods
Description from ISM: Authentication methods susceptible to replay attacks are disabled.

Title from Copilot: Disable LAN Manager/NTLM auth methods
Description from ISM: LAN Manager and NT LAN Manager authentication methods are disabled.

Title from Copilot: Do not use security questions for auth
Description from ISM: Security questions are not used for authentication purposes.

Title from Copilot: Do not use email for out-of-band auth
Description from ISM: Email is not used for out-of-band authentication purposes.

Title from Copilot: Use MFA for org online services with sensitive data
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate users to their organisation’s online services that process, store or communicate their organisation’s sensitive data.

Title from Copilot: Use MFA for third-party services handling sensitive data
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate users to third-party online services that process, store or communicate their organisation’s sensitive data.

Title from Copilot: Use MFA (where available) for third-party non-sensitive services
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication (where available) is used to authenticate users to third-party online services that process, store or communicate their organisation’s non-sensitive data.

Title from Copilot: Use MFA for customer services with sensitive customer data
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate users to their organisation’s online customer services that process, store or communicate their organisation’s sensitive customer data.

Title from Copilot: Use MFA for third-party customer services with sensitive data
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate users to third-party online customer services that process, store or communicate their organisation’s sensitive customer data.

Title from Copilot: Use MFA for customer authentication for sensitive data
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate customers to online customer services that process, store or communicate sensitive customer data.

Title from Copilot: Disable non-MFA protocols when MFA used
Description from ISM: When multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate users or customers to online services or online customer services, all other authentication protocols that do not support multi-factor authentication are disabled.

Title from Copilot: Use MFA for privileged users
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate privileged users of systems.

Title from Copilot: Use MFA for unprivileged users
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate unprivileged users of systems.

Title from Copilot: Use MFA for data repository users
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate users of data repositories.

Title from Copilot: MFA uses possession+knowledge or possession unlocked by knowledge/biometrics
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication uses either: something users have and something users know, or something users have that is unlocked by something users know or are.

Title from Copilot: Use phishing-resistant MFA for online services
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication used for authenticating users of online services is phishing-resistant.

Title from Copilot: Provide phishing-resistant MFA option for customer services
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication used for authenticating customers of online customer services provides a phishing-resistant option.

Title from Copilot: Customer MFA is phishing-resistant
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication used for authenticating customers of online customer services is phishing-resistant.

Title from Copilot: Use phishing-resistant MFA for system users
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication used for authenticating users of systems is phishing-resistant.

Title from Copilot: Use phishing-resistant MFA for data repository users
Description from ISM: Multi-factor authentication used for authenticating users of data repositories is phishing-resistant.

Title from Copilot: Disable weaker MFA when phishing-resistant used
Description from ISM: When phishing-resistant multi-factor authentication is used by user accounts, other non-phishing-resistant multi-factor authentication options are disabled for such user accounts.

Title from Copilot: Prevent self-enrol from untrustworthy devices for sensitive MFA
Description from ISM: When multi-factor authentication is used to authenticate users to online services, online customer services, systems or data repositories – that process, store or communicate their organisation’s sensitive data or sensitive customer data – users are prevented from self-enrolling into multi-factor authentication from untrustworthy devices.

Title from Copilot: Log successful/unsuccessful MFA events centrally
Description from ISM: Successful and unsuccessful multi-factor authentication events are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: When MFA unsupported, use passwords only
Description from ISM: When systems cannot support multi-factor authentication, single-factor authentication using passwords is implemented instead.

Title from Copilot: Log successful/unsuccessful single-factor auth events
Description from ISM: Successful and unsuccessful single-factor authentication events are centrally logged.

Title from Copilot: Password min length for MFA on non-classified systems = 6
Description from ISM: Passwords used for multi-factor authentication on non-classified, OFFICIAL: Sensitive and PROTECTED systems are a minimum of 6 characters.

Title from Copilot: Password min length for MFA on SECRET systems = 8
Description from ISM: Passwords used for multi-factor authentication on SECRET systems are a minimum of 8 characters.

Title from Copilot: Password min length for MFA on TOP SECRET systems = 10
Description from ISM: Passwords used for multi-factor authentication on TOP SECRET systems are a minimum of 10 characters.

Title from Copilot: Single-factor password min length for non-classified = 15
Description from ISM: Passwords used for single-factor authentication on non-classified, OFFICIAL: Sensitive and PROTECTED systems are a minimum of 15 characters.

Title from Copilot: Single-factor password min length for SECRET systems = 17
Description from ISM: Passwords used for single-factor authentication on SECRET systems are a minimum of 17 characters.

Title from Copilot: Single-factor password min length for TOP SECRET systems = 20
Description from ISM: Passwords used for single-factor authentication on TOP SECRET systems are a minimum of 20 characters.

Title from Copilot: Passphrases not using predictable constructions; min words specified
Description from ISM:
Passwords using a sequence of words for single-factor authentication are not constructed using:
• a list of categorised words
• a real sentence in a natural language
• song lyrics, movie or television show quotes, literature, or any other publicly available material
• less than 4 random words for non-classified, OFFICIAL: Sensitive and PROTECTED systems; 5 random words for SECRET systems; or 6 random words for TOP SECRET systems.

Title from Copilot: Do not use compromised/common passwords
Description from ISM: Passwords appearing in lists of commonly used passwords or lists of compromised passwords are not used.

Title from Copilot: Password max length limits >=64 characters
Description from ISM: Maximum length limits for passwords are not less than 64 characters.

Title from Copilot: Do not impose password complexity requirements
Description from ISM: Password complexity requirements are not imposed for passwords.

Title from Copilot: Support all ASCII printable characters for passwords
Description from ISM: All ASCII printable characters are supported for passwords.

Title from Copilot: Require sufficient identity evidence for new credentials
Description from ISM: Users provide sufficient evidence to verify their identity when requesting new credentials.

Title from Copilot: Randomly generate credentials for user accounts
Description from ISM: Credentials set for user accounts are randomly generated.

Title from Copilot: Provide credentials via secure channel or split delivery
Description from ISM: Credentials are provided to users via a secure communications channel or, if not possible, split into two parts with one part provided to users and the other part provided to supervisors.

Title from Copilot: Change provided credentials on first use
Description from ISM: Credentials provided to users are changed on first use.

Title from Copilot: Prevent credential reuse across systems
Description from ISM: Credentials are not reused by users across different systems.

Title from Copilot: Manage built-in Administrator credentials securely
Description from ISM: Credentials for the built-in Administrator account in each domain are long, unique, unpredictable and managed.

Title from Copilot: Manage break glass/local admin/service account credentials securely
Description from ISM: Credentials for break glass accounts, local administrator accounts and service accounts are long, unique, unpredictable and managed.

Title from Copilot: Ensure admin/breakglass/service account creds are >=30 chars
Description from ISM: Credentials for built-in Administrator accounts, break glass accounts, local administrator accounts and service accounts are a minimum of 30 characters.

Title from Copilot: Randomly generate admin/breakglass/service account creds
Description from ISM: Credentials for built-in Administrator accounts, break glass accounts, local administrator accounts and service accounts are randomly generated.

Title from Copilot: Create service accounts as group Managed Service Accounts
Description from ISM: Service accounts are created as group Managed Service Accounts.

Title from Copilot: Change credentials if compromised or stored/transmitted in clear
Description from ISM:
Credentials for user accounts are changed if:
• they are compromised
• they are suspected of being compromised
• they are discovered stored on networks in the clear
• they are discovered being transferred across networks in the clear
• membership of a shared user account changes.

Title from Copilot: Change computer account creds if compromised or >30 days
Description from ISM: Credentials for computer accounts are changed if they are compromised, they are suspected of being compromised or they have not been changed in the past 30 days.

Title from Copilot: Change KRBTGT service account creds twice after compromise
Description from ISM: Credentials for the Kerberos Key Distribution Center’s service account (KRBTGT) are changed twice, allowing for replication to all Microsoft AD DS domain controllers in-between each change, if the domain has been directly compromised, the domain is suspected of being compromised or they have not been changed in the past 12 months.

Title from Copilot: Change AD FS token certs twice if compromised
Description from ISM: Microsoft AD FS token-signing and encryption certificates are changed twice in quick succession if they are compromised, they are suspected of being compromised or they have not been changed in the past 12 months.

Title from Copilot: Obscure credentials during entry
Description from ISM: Credentials are obscured as they are entered into systems.

Title from Copilot: Do not use credential hint functionality
Description from ISM: Credential hint functionality is not used for systems.

Title from Copilot: Keep physical credentials separate from systems except during auth
Description from ISM: Physical credentials are kept separate from systems they are used to authenticate to, except for when performing authentication activities.

Title from Copilot: Protect stored credentials with password manager/HSM/salting+hashing
Description from ISM: Credentials stored on systems are protected by a password manager; a hardware security module; or by salting, hashing and stretching them before storage within a database.

Title from Copilot: Protect CA private keys in HSM
Description from ISM: Private keys for Microsoft AD CS CA servers are protected by a hardware security module.

Title from Copilot: Enable memory integrity functionality
Description from ISM: Memory integrity functionality is enabled.

Title from Copilot: Enable Local Security Authority protection
Description from ISM: Local Security Authority protection functionality is enabled.

Title from Copilot: Enable Credential Guard
Description from ISM: Credential Guard functionality is enabled.

Title from Copilot: Enable Remote Credential Guard
Description from ISM: Remote Credential Guard functionality is enabled.

Title from Copilot: Limit cached credentials to one previous logon
Description from ISM: Cached credentials are limited to one previous logon.

Title from Copilot: Scan networks monthly for credentials stored in clear
Description from ISM: Networks are scanned at least monthly to identify any credentials that are being stored in the clear.

Title from Copilot: Lock out accounts after max five failed logons
Description from ISM: User accounts, except for break glass accounts, are locked out after a maximum of five failed logon attempts.

Title from Copilot: Terminate out-of-hours sessions daily and restart workstations
Description from ISM: On a daily basis, outside of business hours and after an appropriate period of inactivity, user sessions are terminated and workstations are restarted.

Title from Copilot: Configure session lock with strict timeout and re-authentication
Description from ISM:
Services are configured with a session lock that:
• activates after a maximum of 15 minutes of user inactivity, a maximum of 12 hours of overall session time or when manually activated by users
• blocks access to all session content
• requires users to re-authenticate using all authentication factors to unlock the session
• denies users the ability to disable the session locking mechanism.

Title from Copilot: Configure screen lock with strict requirements
Description from ISM:
Systems are configured with a screen lock that:
• activates after a maximum of 15 minutes of user inactivity, or when manually activated by users
• conceals all content on the screen
• ensures that the screen does not enter a power saving state before the screen lock is activated
• requires users to re-authenticate using all authentication factors to unlock the system
• denies users the ability to disable the screen locking mechanism.

Title from Copilot: Systems have logon banner reminding security responsibilities
Description from ISM: Systems have a logon banner that reminds users of their security responsibilities when accessing the system and its resources.

Title from Copilot: Use secure-by-design isolation mechanisms for shared hardware
Description from ISM: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the isolation mechanism is from a vendor that has demonstrated a commitment to Secure by Design and Secure by Default principles and practices, including secure programming practices and either memory-safe programming languages or less preferably memory-safe programming practices.

Title from Copilot: Harden isolation configs and restrict admin interfaces
Description from ISM: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the configuration of the isolation mechanism is hardened by removing unneeded functionality and restricting access to the administrative interface used to manage the isolation mechanism.

Title from Copilot: Harden underlying OS when using software isolation
Description from ISM: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the underlying operating system is hardened.

Title from Copilot: Patch isolation mechanisms and underlying OS promptly
Description from ISM: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, patches, updates or vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities are applied to the isolation mechanism and underlying operating system in a timely manner.

Title from Copilot: Replace isolation mechanism/OS when vendor support ends
Description from ISM: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, the isolation mechanism or underlying operating system is replaced when it is no longer supported by a vendor.

Title from Copilot: Perform integrity monitoring and logging for isolation mechanisms
Description from ISM: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware, integrity monitoring and centralised event logging is performed for the isolation mechanism and underlying operating system.

Title from Copilot: Ensure same classification/security domain for shared hardware in SECRET/TOP SECRET
Description from ISM: When using a software-based isolation mechanism to share a physical server’s hardware for SECRET or TOP SECRET computing environments, the physical server and all computing environments are of the same classification and belong to the same security domain.

Title from Copilot: System administration processes and procedures maintained
Description from ISM: System administration processes, and supporting system administration procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Admins follow system change/config plan
Description from ISM: System administrators perform system administration activities in accordance with the system’s change and configuration management plan.

Title from Copilot: Use Secure Admin Workstations for admin tasks
Description from ISM: Secure Admin Workstations are used in the performance of administrative activities.

Title from Copilot: Privileged users use separate privileged/unprivileged environments
Description from ISM: Privileged users use separate privileged and unprivileged operating environments.

Title from Copilot: Do not virtualise privileged environments within unprivileged ones
Description from ISM: Privileged operating environments are not virtualised within unprivileged operating environments.

Title from Copilot: Unprivileged accounts cannot logon to privileged environments
Description from ISM: Unprivileged user accounts cannot logon to privileged operating environments.

Title from Copilot: Privileged accounts cannot logon to unprivileged environments
Description from ISM: Privileged user accounts (excluding local administrator accounts) cannot logon to unprivileged operating environments.

Title from Copilot: DCSync accounts cannot logon to unprivileged environments
Description from ISM: User accounts with DCSync permissions cannot logon to unprivileged operating environments.

Title from Copilot: Segregate administrative infrastructure from network/internet
Description from ISM: Administrative infrastructure is segregated from the wider network and the internet.

Title from Copilot: Segregate admin infrastructure by server criticality
Description from ISM: Administrative infrastructure for critical servers, high-value servers and regular servers is segregated from each other.

Title from Copilot: Network management traffic originates only from admin infrastructure
Description from ISM: Network management traffic can only originate from administrative infrastructure.

Title from Copilot: Conduct admin activities through jump servers
Description from ISM: Administrative activities are conducted through jump servers.

Title from Copilot: Non-admin network devices cannot initiate admin infra connections
Description from ISM: Network devices that do not belong to administrative infrastructure cannot initiate connections with administrative infrastructure.

Title from Copilot: Patch management processes maintained
Description from ISM: Patch management processes, and supporting patch management procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title from Copilot: Centralised managed patching approach used
Description from ISM: A centralised and managed approach that maintains the integrity of patches or updates, and confirms that they have been applied successfully, is used to patch or update applications, operating systems, drivers and firmware.

Title from Copilot: Software registers for IT equipment maintained
Description from ISM: Software registers for workstations, servers, network devices and networked IT equipment are developed, implemented, maintained and verified on a regular basis.

Title from Copilot: Software registers include versions and patch histories
Description from ISM: Software registers contain versions and patch histories of applications, drivers, operating systems and firmware.

Title from Copilot: Automated asset discovery used at least fortnightly
Description from ISM: An automated method of asset discovery is used at least fortnightly to support the detection of assets for subsequent vulnerability scanning activities.

Title from Copilot: Use vulnerability scanner with up-to-date DB
Description from ISM: A vulnerability scanner with an up-to-date vulnerability database is used for vulnerability scanning activities.

Title from Copilot: Daily scanning for online service vulnerabilities
Description from ISM: A vulnerability scanner is used at least daily to identify missing patches or updates for vulnerabilities in online services.

Title from Copilot: Weekly scanning for office/browser/email/security products
Description from ISM: A vulnerability scanner is used at least weekly to identify missing patches or updates for vulnerabilities in office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, and security products.

Title from Copilot: Fortnightly scanning for other applications
Description from ISM: A vulnerability scanner is used at least fortnightly to identify missing patches or updates for vulnerabilities in applications other than office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, and security products.

Title from Copilot: Daily scanning for internet-facing OS of servers/network devices
Description from ISM: A vulnerability scanner is used at least daily to identify missing patches or updates for vulnerabilities in operating systems of internet-facing servers and internet-facing network devices.

Title from Copilot: Fortnightly scanning for workstations/non-internet servers
Description from ISM: A vulnerability scanner is used at least fortnightly to identify missing patches or updates for vulnerabilities in operating systems of workstations, non-internet-facing servers and non-internet-facing network devices.

Title from Copilot: Fortnightly scanning for other IT equipment OS
Description from ISM: A vulnerability scanner is used at least fortnightly to identify missing patches or updates for vulnerabilities in operating systems of IT equipment other than workstations, servers and network devices.

Title from Copilot: Fortnightly driver vulnerability scanning
Description from ISM: A vulnerability scanner is used at least fortnightly to identify missing patches or updates for vulnerabilities in drivers.

Title from Copilot: Fortnightly firmware vulnerability scanning
Description from ISM: A vulnerability scanner is used at least fortnightly to identify missing patches or updates for vulnerabilities in firmware.

Title from Copilot: Assess compromise likelihood when working exploits exist
Description from ISM: The likelihood of system compromise is frequently assessed when working exploits exist for unmitigated vulnerabilities.

Title from Copilot: Apply critical online service patches within 48 hours for critical/exploited
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in online services are applied within 48 hours of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as critical by vendors or when working exploits exist.

Title from Copilot: Apply non-critical online service patches within two weeks
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in online services are applied within two weeks of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as non-critical by vendors and no working exploits exist.

Title from Copilot: Apply patches for office/browser/email/security products within two weeks
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, and security products are applied within two weeks of release.

Title from Copilot: Apply critical patches for office/browser/email within 48 hours
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, and security products are applied within 48 hours of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as critical by vendors or when working exploits exist.

Title from Copilot: Apply non-critical office/browser/email patches within two weeks
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, and security products are applied within two weeks of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as non-critical by vendors and no working exploits exist.

Title from Copilot: Apply app patches within one month for non-critical
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in applications other than office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, and security products are applied within one month of release.

Title from Copilot: Apply critical internet-facing OS patches within 48 hours

Title from Copilot: Apply workstation/non-internet server OS patches within one month
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in operating systems of workstations, non-internet-facing servers and non-internet-facing network devices are applied within one month of release.

Title from Copilot: Apply critical patches for workstations within 48 hours

Title from Copilot: Apply non-critical workstation patches within one month

Title from Copilot: Apply critical patches for other IT equipment OS within 48 hours

Title from Copilot: Apply non-critical patches for other IT equipment within one month
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in operating systems of IT equipment other than workstations, servers and network devices are applied within one month of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as non-critical by vendors and no working exploits exist.

Title from Copilot: Apply critical driver patches within 48 hours
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in drivers are applied within 48 hours of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as critical by vendors or when working exploits exist.

Title from Copilot: Apply non-critical driver patches within one month

Title from Copilot: Apply critical firmware patches within 48 hours

Title from Copilot: Apply non-critical firmware patches within one month
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in firmware are applied within one month of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as non-critical by vendors and no working exploits exist.

Title from Copilot: Remove unsupported other applications
Description from ISM: Applications other than office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, Adobe Flash Player, and security products that are no longer supported by vendors are removed.

Title from Copilot: Replace unsupported internet-facing network devices
Description from ISM: Internet-facing network devices that are no longer supported by vendors are replaced.

Title from Copilot: Replace unsupported non-internet network devices
Description from ISM: Non-internet-facing network devices that are no longer supported by vendors are replaced.

Title from Copilot: Replace unsupported networked IT equipment
Description from ISM: Networked IT equipment that is no longer supported by vendors is replaced.

Title from Copilot: Implement compensating controls until removal/replacement possible
Description from ISM: When applications, operating systems, network devices or networked IT equipment that are no longer supported by vendors cannot be immediately removed or replaced, compensating controls are implemented until such time that they can be removed or replaced.

Title from Copilot: Digital preservation policy maintained
